 juices
 energy drinks and
 to a lesser extent
 carbonated soft drinks.&#xa0; We believe our creative product designs
 innovative packaging and imaginative flavors
 along with our corporate culture and philosophy
 make National Beverage unique as a stand-alone entity in the beverage industry.&#xa0;
  
  
  
  
  
Building on a rich tradition of flavor and brand innovation with more than a 130-year history of development with iconic brands such as Shasta&#xae; and Faygo&#xae;
 we have extended our flavor and essence leadership and technical expertise to the sparkling water category.&#xa0; Proprietary flavors and our naturally-essenced beverages are developed and tested in-house and made commercially available only after extensive concept and sensory evaluation.&#xa0; Our variety of distinctive flavors provides us a unique advantage with today&#x2019;s consumers who demand variety and refreshing beverage alternatives.
  




       1







      




  
 &#x2013; We believe that innovative marketing
 packaging and consumer engagement is more effective in today&#x2019;s marketplace than traditional higher-cost national advertising.&#xa0; In addition to our cost-effective social media platforms
 we utilize regionally-focused marketing programs and in-store &#x201c;brand ambassadors&#x201d; to interact with and obtain feedback from our consumers.&#xa0; We also believe the design of our packages and the overall optical effect of their placement on the shelf (&#x201c;shelf marketing&#x201d;) has become more important as millennials and younger generations become increasingly influential consumers
 and are now influencing baby boomers and older generations.&#xa0;
  


    


       
 &#x2013; In a beverage industry dominated by the &#x201c;cola giants&#x201d;
 we pride ourselves on being able to respond faster and more creatively to consumer trends than competitors burdened by legacy production and distribution complexity and costs.&#xa0; The ability to identify consumer trends and create new market-leading concepts define our new product development model.&#xa0; Speed to market with the appropriate concept
 unique flavor creation and trend-forward &#x2018;better-for-you&#x2019; ingredients continues to be our goal.&#xa0; Internal development teams are responsible for concept creation
 packaging and design
Presently
 our primary market focus is the United States and Canada.&#xa0; Certain of our products are also distributed on a limited basis in other countries and options to expand distribution to other regions are being considered.&#xa0;



  

 the terms &#x201c;we
&#x201d; &#x201c;us
&#x201d; &#x201c;our
&#x201d; &#x201c;Company&#x201d; and &#x201c;National Beverage&#x201d; mean National Beverage Corp. and its subsidiaries unless indicated otherwise.&#xa0;
  
  
  
  

 energy drinks
 and juices. Our portfolio of Power+ Brands includes LaCroix&#xae;
 LaCroix C&#xfa;rate&#xae;
 and LaCroix NiCola&#xae; sparkling water products; Clear Fruit&#xae;; Rip It&#xae; energy drinks and shots; and Everfresh&#xae;
 Everfresh Premier Varietals&#x2122; and Mr. Pure&#xae; 100% juice and juice-based products.&#xa0; Additionally
 we produce and distribute carbonated soft drinks (&#x201c;CSDs&#x201d;) including Shasta&#xa0;and Faygo
 iconic brands whose consumer loyalty spans more than 130 years.&#xa0;
  




       2







      




  
  
  
  
  


    


       
LaCroix&#xae; Sparkling Water
 our most significant brand
 calories
 sodium
 LaCroix leads the premium domestic sparkling water category. Naturally essenced
 LaCroix has gained the support of national retailers in multiple channels
 including mass-merchandisers
 club stores
 drug stores
In Fiscal year 2020
 LaCroix launched three new naturally-essenced flavors of LaCroix: Hi-Biscus is a unique flavor that adds the delicate essence of the hibiscus flower to sparkling water
 the enticing savor of LimonCello instantly transports fans to the Italian Riviera and the refreshing taste of Past&#xe8;que captures the lusciousness of a sweet picnic watermelon.&#xa0;



  

 LaCroix launched its innovative new trio of Beach Plum
 Black Razzberry&#xa0;and Guava S&#xe3;o Paulo. Beach Plum excites the imagination and inspires&#xa0;dreams of summer with the delectable coolness of the luscious fruit native to the east coast of the U.S.; the sweet twist of Black Razzberry makes taste buds sing with decadent
 smooth and irresistible fruit flavor; and consumers savor the sweet tropical delicacy and vibrant essence of Guava S&#xe3;o Paulo.
  
  


    
LaCroix&#x2019;s dynamic &#x2018;theme&#x2019; LaCroix C&#xfa;rate&#xae; (&#x2018;Cure Yourself&#x2019;) celebrates French sophistication with Spanish zest and bold flavor pairings.&#xa0; C&#xfa;rate naturally refreshes in tall
 sleek 12 oz. consumer-friendly cans.&#xa0; Eloquent graphics
 robust aroma
 naturally &#x2018;essenced&#x2019; and premium-priced
 C&#xfa;rate is an attractive alternative for today&#x2019;s consumers.


       



  

 an innovative sparkling water
&#x2019; effect of no calories
 sodium
 sweetener or any other ingredient that the health-conscious consumer avoids.&#xa0; NiCola is designed for those cola and diet cola consumers within the $83 billion U.S. carbonated soft drink market that are looking to continue to quench their cola-craving taste without negative health consequences.&#xa0; Our LaCroix NiCola theme includes traditional La Cola along with Coconut Cola
 Cubana (Mojito)
 and Coffea Exotica (Sumatra coffee and cola).

Clear Fruit is a crisp
 clear

 including consumer favorites Cherry Blast
 Strawberry Watermelon
 and Fruit Punch. Clear Fruit is available in 20-ounce and 16.9-ounce bottles with consumer-favored sports caps.&#xa0;

       4







      




  
  
  


    


       
Shasta&#xae; has been recognized as a bottling industry pioneer and innovator for more than 130 years. Shasta features multiple flavors and has earned consumer loyalty by delivering value and convenience with such unique tastes as Raspberry Cr&#xe8;me
 Tiki Punch
With more than 110 years of brand history
&#xa0; Faygo&#xae; products include numerous unique flavors such as Red Pop&#xae;
 Moon Mist&#xae;
 and Rock&#x2019;n&#x2019;Rye&#xae;.&#xa0; Faygo is celebrated in the Midwest as The One True Pop.



  


    
Many of our carbonated soft drink brands enjoy a regional identification that fosters long-term consumer loyalty and makes them more competitive as a consumer choice.&#xa0; In addition
In recent years
 we reformulated many of our brands to reduce caloric content while still preserving their time-tested flavor profiles.&#xa0; Our brands
 optically and ingredient-wise
 are continually evolving. We always strive to make all our drinks healthier while maintaining their iconic taste profiles.


       



  
  
  
  


    


       





  

 distribution and marketing of our brands
 we believe we can more effectively manage quality control and consumer appeal while responding quickly to changing market conditions.&#xa0;
  




       5







      




  




 we are able to produce beverages in accordance with uniform quality standards while innovating flavors to meet changing consumer preferences.&#xa0; We believe the combination of a Company-owned bottling network
 together with uniform standards for packaging
 formulations and customer service



       



  
  
  
  

 as well as thousands of smaller &#x201c;up-and-down-the-street&#x201d; accounts
 we utilize a hybrid distribution system to deliver our products through three primary distribution channels: take-home
 convenience and food-service.&#xa0;
  

 club stores
 mass-merchandisers
 wholesalers
 e-commerce stores
 drug stores and dollar stores.&#xa0; We distribute our products to this channel primarily through the warehouse distribution system and
 to a lesser extent
 the direct-store delivery system.
  


    
Warehouse distribution system&#xa0;products are shipped from our production facilities to the retailer&#x2019;s centralized distribution centers and then distributed by the retailer to each of its store locations with other goods.&#xa0; This method allows our retail partners to further maximize their assets by utilizing their ability to pick-up product at our warehouses
We distribute our products to the convenience channel through our own direct-store delivery fleet and those of independent distributors.&#xa0; The convenience channel consists of convenience stores
 gas stations and other smaller &#x201c;up-and-down-the-street&#x201d; accounts.&#xa0; Because of the higher retail prices and margins that typically prevail
 we have developed packaging and graphics specifically targeted to this market.


       



  

 specialized distributors who sell to hospitals
 schools
 military bases
 airlines
 hotels and food-service wholesalers.&#xa0; Also
 our Company-owned direct-store delivery fleet distributes products to select&#xa0;schools and food-service locations.
  




       6







      




  

 convenience and food-service operations use vending machines and glass-door coolers as marketing and promotional tools for our brands.&#xa0; We provide vending machines and coolers on a placement or purchase basis to our customers.&#xa0; We believe vending and cooler equipment expands on-site visual trial
 thereby increasing sales and enhancing brand awareness.
  
  
  
  


    


       
We sell and market our products through an internal sales force as well as specialized broker networks. Our sales force is organized to serve a specific market
 focusing on one or more geographic territories
 distribution channels or product lines.&#xa0; We believe this focus allows our sales group to provide high level
Our marketing emphasizes programs designed to reach consumers directly through innovative digital marketing
 digital social marketing
 social media engagement
Additionally
 we maintain and enhance consumer brand recognition and loyalty through a combination of participation in regional events
 special event marketing
 endorsements
 consumer coupon distribution and product sampling.&#xa0; We also offer numerous promotional programs to retail customers
 including cooperative advertising support
&#x2019; ambassadors
 in-store promotional activities and other incentives.&#xa0; These elements allow marketing and other consumer programs to be tailored to meet local and regional demographics.



  
  
  
  


    
Our centralized procurement group maintains relationships with numerous suppliers of ingredients and packaging.&#xa0; By consolidating the purchasing function for our production facilities
 we believe we are able to procure more competitive arrangements with our suppliers
The products we produce and sell are made from various materials including aluminum cans
 glass and plastic bottles
 water
 carbon dioxide
 juice and flavor concentrates
 sweeteners
 cartons and closures.&#xa0; We craft a substantial portion of our flavors and concentrates while purchasing the remaining raw materials from multiple suppliers.


       



  




       7







      




  

 although strikes
 weather conditions
 utility shortages
 governmental control or regulations
 national emergencies
 quality
 price or supply fluctuations or other events outside our control could adversely affect the supply of specific materials.&#xa0; A significant portion of our raw material purchases
 including aluminum cans
 plastic bottles
 high fructose corn syrup
 corrugated packaging and juice concentrates
 are derived from commodities.&#xa0; Therefore
 pricing and availability tend to fluctuate based upon worldwide commodity market conditions.&#xa0; In certain cases
 we may elect to enter into multi-year agreements for the supply of these materials with one or more suppliers
 the terms of which may include variable or fixed pricing
 minimum purchase quantities and/or the requirement to purchase all supplies for specified locations.&#xa0; Additionally
 we use derivative financial instruments to partially mitigate our exposure to changes in certain raw material costs.
  
  
  
  


    


       

 including fluctuations in costs of raw materials




  
  
  
  

 the beverage industry is highly competitive and our competitive position may vary by market area.&#xa0; Our products compete with many varieties of liquid refreshment
 including water products
 soft drinks
 juices
 fruit drinks
 energy drinks and sports drinks
 as well as powdered drinks
 coffees
 teas
 dairy-based drinks
 functional beverages and various other nonalcoholic beverages.&#xa0; We compete with bottlers and distributors of national
 regional and private label products. Several competitors
 including those that dominate the beverage industry
 such as Nestl&#xe9; S.A.
 PepsiCo and The Coca-Cola Company
 have greater financial resources than we have and aggressive promotion of their products may adversely affect sales of our brands.&#xa0;

 key brand recognition

 efficient distribution methods

 of which 368 are covered by collective bargaining agreements.&#xa0; These collective bargaining agreements generally address working conditions
 as well as wage rates and benefits
 and expire over varying terms over the next several years.&#xa0; We believe these agreements can be renegotiated on terms satisfactory to us as they expire and we believe we maintain good relationships with our employees and their representative organizations.&#xa0;

 mental and financial health of our employees.&#xa0; Our employee benefits program includes comprehensive health

       9







      




  

 supplemented by risk management professionals
 review all&#xa0;aspects of employee tasks and work environment to minimize risk.&#xa0;We strive to achieve an injury-free work environment in our operations.&#xa0; Key to these efforts are data analysis and preventative actions.&#xa0; We measure and benchmark lost time incident rate
 a reliable indication of total recordable injuries rate and severity
 and use a risk reduction process that thoroughly analyzes injuries and near misses.
  

 we have taken extraordinary measures to safeguard the well-being of our employees.&#xa0;These measures include enhanced and comprehensive sanitation procedures
&#xa0;physical distancing
 and health protocols
 remote working for most office employees
 technology enhancements
 and temporary financial incentives for employees working diligently to manufacture and distribute beverages for their communities.&#xa0;
  
  
  

 providing thousands of jobs in local communities and boasting a lower carbon footprint than imported brands.&#xa0;In addition
 the majority of our products are delivered through the warehouse distribution system which provides more&#xa0;efficient and lower greenhouse gas emissions than direct-store delivery competitors.
  

 which generally contain approximately 73% recycled material. Each of our facilities has programs in place designed to minimize the use of water

       10







      




  
  
  

 the following risk factors should be considered carefully in evaluating the Company&#x2019;s business.&#xa0; Our business
 financial condition
&#xa0;results of operations and cash flows could be materially and adversely affected by any of these risks.&#xa0; Additional risks and uncertainties
 including risks and uncertainties not presently known to the Company
 or that the Company currently deems immaterial
 may also impair our business and financial results.
  
&#xa0; Our beverage portfolio is comprised of a number of unique brands with reputations and consumer loyalty that have been built over time.&#xa0; Our investments in social media and marketing as well as our strong commitment to product quality are intended to have a favorable impact on brand image and consumer preferences.&#xa0; Unfavorable publicity
 or allegations of quality issues
 even if false or unfounded
 may tarnish our reputation and brand image and cause consumers to choose other products.&#xa0; In addition
 if we do not adequately anticipate and react to changing demographics
 consumer trends
 health concerns and product preferences
 our financial results could be adversely affected.
  
The beverage industry is extremely competitive.&#xa0; Our products compete with a broad range of beverage products
 most of which are manufactured and distributed by companies with substantially greater financial
 marketing and distribution resources.&#xa0; Discounting and other actions by our competitors could adversely affect our ability to sustain revenues and profits.
  
Our retail customer base has been consolidating over many years resulting in fewer customers with increased purchasing power.&#xa0; This increased purchasing power can limit our ability to increase pricing for our products with certain of our customers.&#xa0; Additionally
 e-commerce transactions and value stores are experiencing rapid growth.&#xa0; Our inability to adapt to customer requirements could lead to a loss of business and adversely affect our financial results.
  
&#xa0; The production of our products is dependent on certain raw materials
 including aluminum
 resin
 corn
 linerboard
 water and fruit juice.&#xa0; In addition
 the production and distribution of our products is dependent on energy sources
 including natural gas
 fuel and electricity.&#xa0; These items are subject to price volatility caused by numerous factors.&#xa0; Commodity price increases ultimately result in a corresponding increase in the cost of raw materials and energy.&#xa0; We may be limited in our ability to pass these increases on to our customers or may incur a loss in sales volume to the extent price increases are taken. In addition
 strikes
 weather conditions
 governmental controls
 tariffs
 national emergencies
 natural disasters
 supply shortages or other events could affect our continued supply and cost of raw materials and energy. If raw materials or energy costs increase
 or their availability is limited
 our financial results could be adversely affected.
  
Our business and properties are subject to various federal
 state and local laws and regulations
 including those governing the production
 packaging
 quality
 labeling and distribution of beverage products.&#xa0; In addition
 various governmental agencies have enacted or are considering changes in corporate tax laws&#xa0;as well as
 additional taxes on soft drinks and other sweetened beverages.&#xa0; Compliance with or changes in existing laws or regulations could require material expenses and negatively affect our financial results through lower sales or higher costs.&#xa0;
  




       11







      




  
&#xa0; Our profitability is affected by the cost of medical
 statutory and other benefits provided to employees
 including employees covered under collective bargaining agreements and multi-employer pension plans.&#xa0; In recent years
 we have experienced increases in these costs
 certain of which are self-insured.&#xa0; Although we seek to limit these cost increases
 continued upward pressure in these costs could reduce our profitability.
  
 Unfavorable weather conditions could have an adverse impact on our revenue and profitability.&#xa0; Unusually cold or rainy weather may temporarily reduce demand for our products and contribute to lower sales
 which could adversely affect our profitability for such periods.&#xa0; Prolonged drought conditions in the geographic regions in which we do business could lead to restrictions on the use of water
 which could adversely affect our ability to produce and distribute products.
  
 Our performance significantly depends upon the continued contributions of our executive officers and key employees
 both individually and as a group
 and our ability to retain and motivate them.&#xa0; Our officers and key personnel have many years of experience with us and in our industry and it may be difficult to replace them.&#xa0; If we lose key personnel or are unable to recruit qualified personnel
 our operations and ability to manage our business may be adversely affected.
  
 The magnitude and duration of the current COVID-19 pandemic is uncertain
 rapidly changing and may be impacted by events beyond our&#xa0;control. Such events could include disruptions in our manufacturing operations or supply arrangements caused by the loss or disruption of essential manufacturing materials
 supplies and services
 transportation resources
 workforce availability
 or other manufacturing and distribution capability.&#xa0; Such events could adversely impact our business and&#xa0;financial results.
  
We use information technology and third-party service providers to support our business processes and activities. Continuity of business applications and services may in the future be disrupted by events such as infection by viruses or malware or other cybersecurity breaches or attacks; issues with systems&#x2019; maintenance or security; power outages; hardware or software failures; telecommunication failures; natural disasters; and other catastrophic occurrences.&#xa0; If our controls
 disaster recovery and business continuity plans or those of our third party providers do not effectively respond to or resolve the issues related to any such disruptions in a timely manner
 our sales
 financial condition and results of operations may be adversely affected.

Property
 plant and equipment - net
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     


     
     
     


     
     
     
     
     
     
     


     
     
     


     
     
     


     



  



     
     






     
The Company paid special cash dividends of $279.9 million ($3.00 per share) on January 29
 2021
 $135.2 million ($1.45&#xa0;per share) on January 29
 2019 and $69.9 million ($.75&#xa0;per share) on August 4
 2017 and January 27
 2017.






     
Fiscal 2020 consisted of 53 weeks
 all other periods consisted of 52 weeks.



  


     16





      




  



     
     



  
  
  

 juices
 energy drinks (Power+ Brands) and
 to a lesser extent
 carbonated soft drinks. We believe our creative product designs
 innovative packaging and imaginative flavors
 along with our corporate culture and philosophy
 make National Beverage unique as a stand-alone entity in the beverage industry.
  

 in recent years
 has transformed to an innovative
 healthier refreshment company. From our corporate philosophy
 development of products and marketing to manufacturing
thirst quencher that compassionately cares for their nutritional health. We are committed to our quest to innovate for the joy
 benefit and enjoyment of our consumers&#x2019; healthier lifestyle!
  
  
  



     
     
The retail industry is in revolution. In prior years
 each retailer induced their consumer with a proprietary brand (especially soft drinks)
 but today understands that the well-informed
 smart consumer is demanding that retailers provide recognizable brands that have earned their respective consumer standing on their merits.



  



     
     
Retail today is in the most competitively-indexed service industry
 without exception. Innovation
 plus the urgent time demands on the consumer
 requires quick
 expedient shopping. Home delivery is even more of a current shoppers&#x2019;&#xa0;choice. Retailers cannot carry slower-moving items that home delivery will not support.



  



     
     
The new consumer is the most competent/knowledgeable product analyzer ever
 and personal mental/physical lifestyles demand that healthier is their preferred choice. Calories must qualify as worthy; sugar being enemy #1 in the life of the Millennial and younger consumers.



  

 packaging and consumer engagement and (iv) responding faster and more creatively to changing consumer trends than larger competitors who are burdened by legacy production and distribution complexity and costs.
  

 our primary market focus is the United States and Canada. Certain of our products are also distributed on a limited basis in other countries and options to expand distribution to other regions are being considered. To service a diverse customer base that includes numerous national retailers
 as well as thousands of smaller &#x201c;up-and-down-the-street&#x201d; accounts
 we utilize a hybrid distribution system consisting of warehouse and direct-store delivery. The warehouse delivery system allows our retail partners to further maximize their assets by utilizing their ability to pick up product at our warehouses
 further lowering their/our product costs.
  




       17







      




  

 the terms &#x201c;we
&#x201d; &#x201c;us
&#x201d; &#x201c;our
&#x201d; &#x201c;Company&#x201d; and &#x201c;National Beverage&#x201d; mean National Beverage Corp. and its subsidiaries unless indicated otherwise.
  

 including fluctuations in the costs of raw materials
 holiday and seasonal programming and weather conditions. While prior years witnessed more seasonality
 higher sales are realized during the summer when outdoor activities are more prevalent.
  

 where new beverages are developed and produced for selective holidays and ceremonial dates
 should not be analyzed on the common three-month (quarterly) periods
 traditionally found acceptable. Today
 costly development projects and seasonal weather periods plus promotional packaging often&#xa0;make quarter-to-quarter comparisons unworthy statistics that&#xa0;force&#xa0;companies to decision making that is&#xa0;not truly beneficial for investors and shareholders alike.

072 million compared to $1
000 million for Fiscal 2020 (which contained 53 weeks). The increase in sales resulted from a 7.1% increase&#xa0;in branded case volume and a minor increase in average selling price per case due primarily to changes in product mix. Power+ Brands volume increased 10.2% and branded carbonated soft drinks volume increased 1.0%.
  
  
  
  

 general and administrative expenses
 the classification of which is consistent with many beverage companies. However
 our gross margin may not be comparable to companies that include shipping and handling costs in cost of sales. See Note 1 of&#xa0;Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
  
Selling
 General and Administrative Expenses

 general and administrative expenses were $193.8 million for Fiscal 2021
 decreasing $10.6 million from Fiscal 2020. Selling
 general and administrative expenses reflect reduced marketing and selling costs
 partially offset by increased shipping and handling costs. As a percent of net sales
 selling
 general and administrative costs decreased to 18.1% in Fiscal 2021 from 20.4% in Fiscal 2020
  
  

 net is primarily interest income of $.6 million for Fiscal 2021 and $3.9 million for Fiscal 2020. The change in interest income is due to lower investment yields and reduced&#xa0;average investment balances.&#xa0;
  
  
  
  


     19





      




  
  
  
  

 2021
 we maintained $100 million unsecured revolving credit facilities
 under which no borrowings were outstanding and $2.5 million was reserved for standby letters of credit. Cash generated from operations is our principal source of funds. We believe that existing capital resources will be sufficient to meet our liquidity and capital requirements for the next twelve months. See Note 5 of &#xa0;Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
  

 plant and equipment amounted to $25.3 million for Fiscal 2021 primarily for&#xa0;capital projects to expand our production capacity
 enhance packaging capabilities or improve efficiencies at our production facilities. We intend to continue production capacity and efficiency improvement projects in Fiscal&#xa0;2022 and expect capital expenditures to be comparable to Fiscal 2021.
  

 2021.
  

 the Company did not repurchase&#xa0;any shares. As of May 1
 2021
 1
313
144 shares had been purchased under the program and 1
886
856 shares were available for repurchase.
  

 we incurred a fee to Corporate Management Advisors
 Inc. (CMA) of $10.7 million for Fiscal 2021 and $10.0 million for Fiscal 2020. At May 1
 2021
 management fees payable to CMA were $2.6 million. See Note 6 of Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
  
  

 $193.8 million was provided by operating activities
 $25.3 million was used in investing activities and $279.4 million was used in financing activities. Cash provided by operating activities increased $16.1 million primarily due to increased net income offset in part by increased working capital requirements. Cash used in investing activities increased due to capital expenditures
 in order to support production efficiencies and volume growth. Cash used in financing activities primarily consists of $279.9 million ($3.00 per share) special cash dividend was paid on January 29
 2021.
  
  

 our working capital declined to $219.8&#xa0;million from $319.0 million at May 2
 2020. The decrease in working capital resulted from lower cash and equivalents due to the January 2021 cash dividend and higher accounts payable
 partially offset by increased inventories and prepaid expenses.&#xa0; Trade receivables increased slightly and days sales outstanding was 30.1 days at May 1
 2021 compared to 29.5 days at May 2
&#xa0;2020. Inventories increased $8.0 million or 12.6% as a result of increases in finished goods and raw materials
 while annual inventory turns increased&#xa0;to 9.6&#xa0;from 9.4 times. As of May 1
 2021
 the current ratio was 2.5 to 1 compared to 3.3 to 1 at May 2
 2020.

Other long-term liabilities include known claims and estimated incurred but not reported claims not otherwise covered by insurance based on actuarial assumptions and historical claims experience. Since the timing and amount of claim payments vary significantly
 we are not able to reasonably estimate future payments for specific periods and therefore such payments have not been included in the table above. These standby letters of credit expire through April 2022 and are expected to be renewed.

 they may ultimately differ from actual results. We believe that the critical accounting policies described in the following paragraphs comprise the most significant estimates and assumptions used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements. For these policies
 we caution that future events rarely develop exactly as estimated and the best estimates routinely require adjustment.
  
  

 generally without requiring collateral. Exposure to credit losses varies by customer principally due to the financial condition of each customer. We monitor our exposure to credit losses and maintain allowances for anticipated losses based on our experience with past due accounts
 collectability and our analysis of customer data.
  




       21







      




  
  

 excluding goodwill and intangible assets not subject to amortization
 are evaluated for impairment on the basis of undiscounted cash flows whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be recoverable. An impaired asset is written down to its estimated fair value based on the best information available. Estimated fair value is generally measured by discounting future cash flows. Goodwill and intangible assets not subject to amortization are evaluated for impairment annually or sooner if we believe such assets may be impaired. An impairment loss is recognized if the carrying amount or
 for goodwill
 the carrying amount of its reporting unit
 is greater than its fair value.
  
  

 more likely than not
 that the benefit of deferred tax assets will not be realized.
  
  

 medical and workers&#x2019; compensation exposures. Accordingly
 we accrue for known claims and estimated incurred but not reported claims not otherwise covered by insurance based on actuarial assumptions and historical claims experience.
  
  

 based on written sales terms that do not allow a right of return except in rare instances. Our products are typically sold on credit; however smaller direct-store delivery accounts may be sold on a cash basis. Our credit terms normally require payment within 30 days of delivery and may allow discounts for early payment. We estimate and reserve for bad debt exposure based on our experience with past due accounts
 collectability and our analysis of customer data.
  

 the aggregate incentive is recorded as a prepaid and amortized over the period of benefit. The recognition of these incentives involves the use of judgment related to performance and sales volume estimates that are made based on historical experience and other factors. Sales incentives are accounted for as a reduction of sales and actual amounts ultimately realized may vary from accrued amounts. Such differences are recorded once determined and have historically not been significant.

 the Company maintains self-insured and deductible programs for workers&#x2019; compensation exposures. The Company accrues for known claims and estimated incurred but not reported claims not otherwise covered by insurance based on actuarial assumptions and historical claims experience. While a third party actuary is employed to advise the Company
 estimating workers&#x2019; compensation exposure is inherently uncertain
 as estimates are generally derived using a variety of actuarial estimation techniques that are dependent upon assumptions and expectations about future events
 many of which are difficult to quantify. As of May 1
 2021 and May 2
 2020
 other liabilities included accruals of $5.9 million and $5.5 million
 respectively
 for estimated non-current risk retention exposures
 of which $4.5 million and $4.3 million was covered by insurance at May 1
 2021 and May 2
 2020
 respectively.
  

 including the use of our actuarial specialist.
  

 among others:
  



     
     
We obtained an understanding of the relevant controls related to the Company&#x2019;s workers&#x2019; compensation liability
 and tested such controls for design and operating effectiveness
 including controls related to management&#x2019;s review of the significant assumptions .



  



     
     
We tested the underlying data
 including historical claims and payroll data
 which served as the basis for the assumptions used by the third party actuary in the actuarial analysis
 to test that the inputs to the actuarial estimates were accurate and complete.



  



     
     
     



  



     
     
With the assistance of our actuarial specialist
 we evaluated the propriety of the reserving techniques utilized for the workers&#x2019; compensation exposures.

 we carried out an evaluation

 including our Chief Executive Officer and Principal Financial Officer
 of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our &#x201c;disclosure controls and procedures&#x201d; (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934
 as amended (the Exchange Act)). Based upon that evaluation
 the Chief Executive Officer and Principal Financial Officer concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective to ensure information required to be disclosed by us in reports we file or submit under the Exchange Act is (1)&#xa0;recorded
 processed
 summarized and reported within the time periods specified in SEC rules and forms and (2)&#xa0;accumulated and communicated to our management
 including our Chief Executive Officer and Principal Financial Officer
 to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
  
  

 as such term is defined in Rule&#xa0;13a-15(f) of the Exchange Act. Under the supervision and with the participation of our management

 our management concluded that our internal control over financial reporting was effective as of May 1

Mr. Nick A. Caporella has served as Chairman of the Board
 Chief Executive Officer and Director since the Company&#x2019;s inception in 1985. Also
 he serves as Chairman of the Nominating Committee. Since 1992
 Mr. Caporella&#x2019;s services have been provided to the Company by Corporate Management Advisors
 Inc.
 a company he owns.






     
Mr. Joseph G. Caporella has served as President since September 2002 and
 prior to that
 as Executive Vice President and Secretary since January 1991. Also
 he has served as a Director since January 1987. Joseph G. Caporella is the son of Nick A. Caporella.






     
Mr. George R. Bracken has served as Executive Vice President - Finance since July 2012. Previously
 he served as Senior Vice President &#x2013; Finance from October 2000 to July 2012 and Vice President and Treasurer from October 1996 to October 2000. Since 1992
 Mr. Bracken&#x2019;s services have been provided to the Company by Corporate Management Advisors
 Inc.

&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;

   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of National Beverage Corp. and all subsidiaries. All significant intercompany transactions and accounts have been eliminated. Our fiscal year ends the Saturday closest to &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; April 30 &lt;/em&gt;and
 as a result
 an additional week is added every &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;five&lt;/em&gt; or &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;six&lt;/em&gt; years. The fiscal year ended &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021 (&lt;/em&gt;Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021&lt;/em&gt;) and fiscal year ended &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; April 27
 2019 (&lt;/em&gt;Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2019&lt;/em&gt;) consisted of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;52&lt;/em&gt; weeks. The fiscal year ended &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020 (&lt;/em&gt;Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/em&gt;) consisted of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;53&lt;/em&gt; weeks.&#160;&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;On &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; February 5
 2021
 &lt;/em&gt;the Company's board of directors declared a &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74459832&gt;one&lt;/span&gt;-for-&lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;one&lt;/em&gt; stock split in the form of a stock dividend.&#160; This dividend was distributed on &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; February 19
 2021 &lt;/em&gt;to shareholders of record on &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; February 16
 2021.&#160; &lt;/em&gt;Share information and earnings per share have been retroactively adjusted to reflect the stock split.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Certain reclassifications have been made to prior period balances in order to conform to the current period's presentation.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Cash and equivalents are comprised of cash and highly liquid securities (consisting primarily of bank deposits and short-term government money-market investments).&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Derivative financial instruments are used to partially mitigate our exposure to changes in certain raw material costs. All derivative financial instruments are recorded at fair value in our consolidated balance sheets. Derivative financial instruments are &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; used for trading or speculative purposes. Credit risk related to derivative financial instruments is managed by requiring high credit standards for counterparties and frequent cash settlements.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Basic earnings per common share is computed by dividing earnings available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period. Diluted earnings per common share is calculated in a similar manner
 but includes the dilutive effect of stock options amounting to 340
000 shares in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021
&lt;/em&gt; 400
000 shares in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/em&gt; and 568
000 shares in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2019.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The estimated fair values of derivative financial instruments are calculated based on market rates to settle the instruments. These values represent the estimated amounts we would receive upon sale
 taking into consideration current market prices and credit worthiness.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;All long-lived assets
 excluding goodwill and intangible assets &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; subject to amortization
 are evaluated for impairment on the basis of undiscounted cash flows whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;&lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; be recoverable. An impaired asset is written down to its estimated fair market value based on the best information available. Estimated fair value is generally measured by discounting future cash flows. Goodwill and intangible assets &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; subject to amortization are evaluated for impairment annually or sooner if management believes such assets &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;be impaired. An impairment loss is recognized if the carrying amount or
 for goodwill
 the carrying amount of its reporting unit
 is greater than its fair value.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company&#x2019;s effective income tax rate is based on estimates of taxes which will ultimately be payable. Deferred taxes are recorded to give recognition to temporary differences between the tax bases of assets or liabilities and their reported amounts in the financial statements. Valuation allowances are established to reduce the carrying amounts of deferred tax assets when it is deemed
 more likely than &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not
&lt;/em&gt; that the benefit of deferred tax assets will &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; be realized.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company maintains self-insured and deductible programs for certain liability
 medical and workers&#x2019; compensation exposures. Accordingly
 the Company accrues for known claims and estimated incurred but &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; reported claims &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; otherwise covered by insurance based on actuarial assumptions and historical claims experience. At &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021
 &lt;/em&gt;and &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020
 &lt;/em&gt;other liabilities included accruals of $5.9 million and $5.5 million
 respectively
 for estimated non-current risk retention exposures
 of which $4.5 million
 was covered by insurance at both dates and included as a component of non-current other assets.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Intangible Assets as of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021 &lt;/em&gt;and &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020 &lt;/em&gt;consisted of non-amortizable acquired trademarks.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Inventories are stated at the lower of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;first&lt;/em&gt;-in
 &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;first&lt;/em&gt;-out cost or market. Adjustments
 if required
 to reduce the cost of inventory to market (net realizable value) are made for estimated excess
 obsolete or impaired balances. Inventories at &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021 &lt;/em&gt;were comprised of finished goods of $43.3 million and raw materials of $28.2 million. Inventories at &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020 &lt;/em&gt;were comprised of finished goods of $39.1 million and raw materials of $24.4 million.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company utilizes a variety of marketing programs
 including cooperative advertising programs with customers
 to advertise and promote our products to consumers. Marketing costs are expensed when incurred
 except for prepaid advertising and production costs
 which are expensed when the advertising takes place. Marketing costs
 which are included in selling
 general and administrative expenses
 totaled $43.4 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021
&lt;/em&gt; $54.8 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/em&gt; and $55.3 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2019.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;

 Plant and Equipment&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Property
 plant and equipment is recorded at cost. Additions
 replacements and betterments are capitalized
 while maintenance and repairs that do &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; extend the useful life of an asset are expensed as incurred. Depreciation is recorded using the straight-line method over estimated useful lives of &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458820&gt;5&lt;/span&gt; to &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458821&gt;30&lt;/span&gt; years for buildings and improvements and &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458822&gt;3&lt;/span&gt; to &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458823&gt;15&lt;/span&gt; years for machinery and equipment. Leasehold improvements are amortized using the straight-line method over the shorter of the remaining lease term or the estimated useful life of the improvement. When assets are retired or otherwise disposed
 the cost and accumulated depreciation are removed from the respective accounts and any related gain or loss is recognized.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;

   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Revenue is recognized upon delivery to our customers
 based on written sales terms that do &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; allow a right of return except in rare instances. Our products are typically sold on credit. However
 smaller direct store delivery accounts &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;be sold on a cash basis. Our credit terms normally require payment within &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;30&lt;/em&gt; days of delivery and &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;allow discounts for early payment. The Company estimates and reserves for bad debt exposure based on our experience with past due accounts
 collectability and our analysis of customer data.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Various sales incentive arrangements are offered to our customers that require customer performance or achievement of certain sales volume targets. Sales incentives are accrued over the period of benefit or expected sales. When the incentive is paid in advance
 the aggregate incentive is recorded as a prepaid and amortized over the period of benefit. The recognition of these incentives involves the use of judgment related to performance and sales volume estimates that are made based on historical experience and other factors. Sales incentives are accounted for as a reduction of sales and actual amounts ultimately realized &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;vary from accrued amounts. Such differences are recorded once determined and have historically &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; been significant.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company operates as a single operating segment for purposes of presenting financial information and evaluating performance. As such
 the accompanying consolidated financial statements present financial information in a format that is consistent with the internal financial information used by management. The Company does &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; accumulate revenues by product classification and
 therefore
 it is impractical to present such information..&#160;&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Shipping and handling costs are reported in selling
 general and administrative expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of income. Such costs aggregated $75.5 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021
&lt;/em&gt; $69.8 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/em&gt; and $72.4 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2019.&lt;/em&gt; Although our classification is consistent with many beverage companies
 our gross margin &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;&lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; be comparable to companies that include shipping and handling costs in cost of sales.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Trade receivables are recorded at net realizable value
 which includes an estimated allowance for doubtful accounts. The Company extends credit based on an evaluation of each customer&#x2019;s financial condition
 generally without requiring collateral. Exposure to credit losses varies by customer principally due to the financial condition of each customer. The Company continually monitors our exposure to credit losses and maintains allowances for anticipated losses based on our experience with past due accounts
 collectability and our analysis of customer data. Actual future losses from uncollectible accounts could differ from the Company&#x2019;s estimate. Changes in the allowance for doubtful accounts was as follows:&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;









&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;As of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021&#160;&lt;/em&gt;and &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020
 &lt;/em&gt;the Company had no customer that comprised more than &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;10%&lt;/em&gt; of trade receivables. No customer accounted for more than &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;10%&lt;/em&gt; of net sales during any of the last &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;three&lt;/em&gt; fiscal years.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The preparation of our financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the financial statements and accompanying notes. Although these estimates are based on management&#x2019;s knowledge of current events and anticipated future actions
 actual results &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;vary from reported amounts.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;/&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and rules and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of National Beverage Corp. and all subsidiaries. All significant intercompany transactions and accounts have been eliminated. Our fiscal year ends the Saturday closest to &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; April 30 &lt;/em&gt;and
 as a result
 an additional week is added every &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;five&lt;/em&gt; or &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;six&lt;/em&gt; years. The fiscal year ended &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021 (&lt;/em&gt;Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021&lt;/em&gt;) and fiscal year ended &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; April 27
 2019 (&lt;/em&gt;Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2019&lt;/em&gt;) consisted of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;52&lt;/em&gt; weeks. The fiscal year ended &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020 (&lt;/em&gt;Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/em&gt;) consisted of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;53&lt;/em&gt; weeks.&#160;&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;On &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; February 5
 2021
 &lt;/em&gt;the Company's board of directors declared a &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74459832&gt;one&lt;/span&gt;-for-&lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;one&lt;/em&gt; stock split in the form of a stock dividend.&#160; This dividend was distributed on &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; February 19
 2021 &lt;/em&gt;to shareholders of record on &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; February 16
 2021.&#160; &lt;/em&gt;Share information and earnings per share have been retroactively adjusted to reflect the stock split.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Certain reclassifications have been made to prior period balances in order to conform to the current period's presentation.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Cash and equivalents are comprised of cash and highly liquid securities (consisting primarily of bank deposits and short-term government money-market investments).&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Derivative financial instruments are used to partially mitigate our exposure to changes in certain raw material costs. All derivative financial instruments are recorded at fair value in our consolidated balance sheets. Derivative financial instruments are &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; used for trading or speculative purposes. Credit risk related to derivative financial instruments is managed by requiring high credit standards for counterparties and frequent cash settlements.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Basic earnings per common share is computed by dividing earnings available to common shareholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period. Diluted earnings per common share is calculated in a similar manner
 but includes the dilutive effect of stock options amounting to 340
000 shares in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021
&lt;/em&gt; 400
000 shares in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/em&gt; and 568
000 shares in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2019.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The estimated fair values of derivative financial instruments are calculated based on market rates to settle the instruments. These values represent the estimated amounts we would receive upon sale
 taking into consideration current market prices and credit worthiness.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;All long-lived assets
 excluding goodwill and intangible assets &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; subject to amortization
 are evaluated for impairment on the basis of undiscounted cash flows whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;&lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; be recoverable. An impairment loss is recognized if the carrying amount or
 for goodwill
 the carrying amount of its reporting unit
 is greater than its fair value.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company&#x2019;s effective income tax rate is based on estimates of taxes which will ultimately be payable. Deferred taxes are recorded to give recognition to temporary differences between the tax bases of assets or liabilities and their reported amounts in the financial statements. Valuation allowances are established to reduce the carrying amounts of deferred tax assets when it is deemed
 more likely than &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not
&lt;/em&gt; that the benefit of deferred tax assets will &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; be realized.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company maintains self-insured and deductible programs for certain liability
 medical and workers&#x2019; compensation exposures. Accordingly
 the Company accrues for known claims and estimated incurred but &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; reported claims &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; otherwise covered by insurance based on actuarial assumptions and historical claims experience. At &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021
 &lt;/em&gt;and &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020
 &lt;/em&gt;other liabilities included accruals of $5.9 million and $5.5 million
 respectively

 of which $4.5 million
 was covered by insurance at both dates and included as a component of non-current other assets.&lt;/p&gt;

      contextRef=i_2020-05-02
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458773


      contextRef=i_2021-05-01
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458774


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Intangible Assets as of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021 &lt;/em&gt;and &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020 &lt;/em&gt;consisted of non-amortizable acquired trademarks.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Inventories are stated at the lower of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;first&lt;/em&gt;-in
 &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;first&lt;/em&gt;-out cost or market. Adjustments
 if required
 to reduce the cost of inventory to market (net realizable value) are made for estimated excess
 obsolete or impaired balances. Inventories at &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021 &lt;/em&gt;were comprised of finished goods of $43.3 million and raw materials of $28.2 million. Inventories at &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020 &lt;/em&gt;were comprised of finished goods of $39.1 million and raw materials of $24.4 million.&lt;/p&gt;


      contextRef=i_2021-05-01
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458779


      contextRef=i_2021-05-01
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458781


      contextRef=i_2020-05-02
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458782


      contextRef=i_2020-05-02
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458783


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company utilizes a variety of marketing programs
 including cooperative advertising programs with customers
 to advertise and promote our products to consumers. Marketing costs are expensed when incurred
 except for prepaid advertising and production costs
 which are expensed when the advertising takes place. Marketing costs
 which are included in selling
 general and administrative expenses
 totaled $43.4 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021
&lt;/em&gt; $54.8 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/em&gt; and $55.3 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2019.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;


      contextRef=d_2020-05-03_2021-05-01
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458785


      contextRef=d_2019-04-28_2020-05-02
      decimals=-5

      contextRef=d_2018-04-29_2019-04-27

      id=c74458790


 Plant and Equipment&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Property
 plant and equipment is recorded at cost. Additions
 replacements and betterments are capitalized
 while maintenance and repairs that do &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; extend the useful life of an asset are expensed as incurred. Depreciation is recorded using the straight-line method over estimated useful lives of &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458820&gt;5&lt;/span&gt; to &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458821&gt;30&lt;/span&gt; years for buildings and improvements and &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458822&gt;3&lt;/span&gt; to &lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458823&gt;15&lt;/span&gt; years for machinery and equipment. Leasehold improvements are amortized using the straight-line method over the shorter of the remaining lease term or the estimated useful life of the improvement. When assets are retired or otherwise disposed
 the cost and accumulated depreciation are removed from the respective accounts and any related gain or loss is recognized.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Revenue is recognized upon delivery to our customers
 based on written sales terms that do &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; allow a right of return except in rare instances. Our products are typically sold on credit. However
 smaller direct store delivery accounts &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;be sold on a cash basis. Our credit terms normally require payment within &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;30&lt;/em&gt; days of delivery and &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;allow discounts for early payment. The Company estimates and reserves for bad debt exposure based on our experience with past due accounts
 collectability and our analysis of customer data.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Various sales incentive arrangements are offered to our customers that require customer performance or achievement of certain sales volume targets. Sales incentives are accrued over the period of benefit or expected sales. When the incentive is paid in advance
 the aggregate incentive is recorded as a prepaid and amortized over the period of benefit. The recognition of these incentives involves the use of judgment related to performance and sales volume estimates that are made based on historical experience and other factors. Sales incentives are accounted for as a reduction of sales and actual amounts ultimately realized &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;vary from accrued amounts. Such differences are recorded once determined and have historically &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; been significant.&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company operates as a single operating segment for purposes of presenting financial information and evaluating performance. As such
 the accompanying consolidated financial statements present financial information in a format that is consistent with the internal financial information used by management. The Company does &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; accumulate revenues by product classification and
 therefore
 it is impractical to present such information..&#160;&lt;/p&gt;


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Shipping and handling costs are reported in selling
 general and administrative expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of income. Such costs aggregated $75.5 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021
&lt;/em&gt; $69.8 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020&lt;/em&gt; and $72.4 million in Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2019.&lt;/em&gt; Although our classification is consistent with many beverage companies
 our gross margin &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;&lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; be comparable to companies that include shipping and handling costs in cost of sales.&lt;/p&gt;


      contextRef=d_2020-05-03_2021-05-01
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458829


      contextRef=d_2019-04-28_2020-05-02
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458831


      contextRef=d_2018-04-29_2019-04-27
      decimals=-5
      id=c74458833


   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Trade receivables are recorded at net realizable value
 which includes an estimated allowance for doubtful accounts. The Company extends credit based on an evaluation of each customer&#x2019;s financial condition
 generally without requiring collateral. Exposure to credit losses varies by customer principally due to the financial condition of each customer. The Company continually monitors our exposure to credit losses and maintains allowances for anticipated losses based on our experience with past due accounts
 collectability and our analysis of customer data. Actual future losses from uncollectible accounts could differ from the Company&#x2019;s estimate. Changes in the allowance for doubtful accounts was as follows:&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;









&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;As of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021&#160;&lt;/em&gt;and &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020
 &lt;/em&gt;the Company had no customer that comprised more than &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;10%&lt;/em&gt; of trade receivables. No customer accounted for more than &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;10%&lt;/em&gt; of net sales during any of the last &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;three&lt;/em&gt; fiscal years.&lt;/p&gt;

Although these estimates are based on management&#x2019;s knowledge of current events and anticipated future actions

   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company has entered into various non-cancelable operating lease agreements for certain of our offices
 buildings
 machinery and equipment expiring at various dates through &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; January 2029. &lt;/em&gt;The Company does &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; assume renewals in our determination of the lease term unless the renewals are deemed to be reasonably assured at lease commencement. Lease agreements generally do &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;not&lt;/em&gt; contain material residual value guarantees or material restrictive covenants. Operating lease cost for Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021&lt;/em&gt; was &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;$13.1&lt;/em&gt; million. The weighted-average remaining lease term and weighted average discount rate of operating leases was 3.06&#160;years and 3.38%
 respectively as of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021. &lt;/em&gt;Net cash provided by operations was impacted by $11.1 million for operating leases for the year ended &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The following is a summary of future minimum lease payments and related liabilities for all non-cancelable operating leases as of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021:&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;

637&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style=width: 1%; font-family: &amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;quot;, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;

800&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style=width: 1%; font-family: &amp;quot;Times New Roman&amp;quot;, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 0pt; padding-bottom: 1px;&gt;)&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;

   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;At &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021
 &lt;/em&gt;a subsidiary of the Company maintained unsecured revolving credit facilities with banks aggregating $100 million (the Credit Facilities). The Credit Facilities expire from &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; October 3
 2020 &lt;/em&gt;to &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; June 18
 2021 &lt;/em&gt;and any borrowings would currently bear interest at 1.0% above &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;one&lt;/em&gt;-month LIBOR. There were no borrowings outstanding under the Credit Facilities at &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021 &lt;/em&gt;or &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020. &lt;/em&gt;At &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021
 &lt;/em&gt;$2.5&#160;million of the Credit Facilities was reserved for standby letters of credit and $97.5&#160;million was available for borrowings.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Credit Facilities require the subsidiary to maintain certain financial ratios
 including debt to net worth and debt to EBITDA (as defined in the Credit Facilities)
 and contain other restrictions
 &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;none&lt;/em&gt; of which are expected to have a material effect on our operations or financial position. At &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021
 &lt;/em&gt;the Company was in compliance with all loan covenants.&lt;/p&gt;

   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Board of Directors has authorized the Company to repurchase up to 3.2&#160;million shares of common stock.&#160; During Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/em&gt; the Company purchased an aggregate 154
512 shares for a cost of $6.2 million. As of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020
 &lt;/em&gt;1
313
144&#160;shares were purchased under the program and 1
886
856&#160;shares were available for repurchase.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company paid a special cash dividend on Common Stock of $279.9 million on &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; January 29
 2021 (&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;&lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458950&gt;$3.00&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/em&gt; per share)
 $135.2 million ($1.45&#160;per share) on &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; January 29
 2019
 &lt;/em&gt;and $69.9 million (&lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74458954&gt;&lt;span style=-sec-ix-hidden:c74460084&gt;$.75&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&#160;per share) on &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; August 4
 2017 &lt;/em&gt;and &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; January 27
 2017.&#160;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The Company is a party to a management agreement with Corporate Management Advisors
 Inc. (CMA)
 a corporation owned by our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. This agreement was originated in &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;1991&lt;/em&gt; for the efficient use of management of &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;two&lt;/em&gt; public companies at the time. In &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;1994
&lt;/em&gt; &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;one&lt;/em&gt; of those public entities
 through a merger
 &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;no&lt;/em&gt; longer was managed in this manner.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;Under the terms of the agreement
 CMA provides
 subject to the direction and supervision of the Board of Directors of the Company
 (i) senior corporate functions (including supervision of the Company&#x2019;s financial
 legal
 executive recruitment
 internal audit and information systems departments) as well as the services of a Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer
 and (ii) services in connection with acquisitions
 dispositions and financings by the Company
 including identifying and profiling acquisition candidates
 negotiating and structuring potential transactions and arranging financing for any such transaction. CMA
 through its personnel
 also provides
 to the extent possible
 the stimulus and creativity to develop an innovative and dynamic persona for the Company
 its products and corporate image. In order to fulfill its obligations under the management agreement
 CMA employs numerous individuals
 who
 acting as a unit
 provide management
 administrative and creative functions for the Company.&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:'Times New Roman';font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;CMA and the Company are joint owners of a corporate aircraft and pursuant to a joint ownership agreement
 each party agreed to pay certain expenses associated with the use of the aircraft.&#160; During the past &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;three&lt;/em&gt; years
 the joint operating costs have averaged approximately $1.0&#160;million&#160;per year and the Company's lease payments for its ownership interest have averaged approximately $.6 million&#160;per year.&#160; In conjunction with an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission (the SEC) for the fiscal years &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2015&lt;/em&gt; through &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/em&gt; the Company initiated a review to determine that the aircraft usage costs were properly classified in accordance with SEC standards.&#160; For purposes of settling these proceedings the Company has volunteered an offer of settlement.&#160; The offer
 if approved by the SEC
 will require an immaterial payment that has been accrued at &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021.&#160; &#160;&#160;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;&#160;&lt;/p&gt;
   &lt;p style=font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;font-variant:normal;text-align:justify;margin:0pt;&gt;The management agreement provides that the Company will pay CMA an annual base fee equal to &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;one&lt;/em&gt; percent of the consolidated net sales of the Company
 and further provides that the Compensation and Stock Option Committee and the Board of Directors &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; may &lt;/em&gt;from time to time award additional incentive compensation to CMA or its personnel. The Board of Directors on numerous occasions contemplated incentive compensation to CMA
 however
 since the inception of this agreement
 &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;no&lt;/em&gt; incentive compensation has been paid. We incurred management fees to CMA of $10.7&#160;million for Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2021
&lt;/em&gt; $10.0 million for Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2020
&lt;/em&gt; and $10.2 million for Fiscal &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;2019.&lt;/em&gt;&#160; Amounts due CMA of $3.8&#160;million at &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 1
 2021
 &lt;/em&gt;which includes &lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt;$1.2&lt;/em&gt;&#160;for costs reimbursable under the management agreement
 and $2.6 million at&#160;&lt;em style=font: inherit;&gt; May 2
 2020.&#160;&#160;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
